Methods for BaseSets Objects

Source: R/AllGenerics.R, R/AllMethods.R, R/BaseSets-class.R
BaseSets-methods.Rd

This page documents the S4 generics and methods defined for objects inheriting of the BaseSets class. In the usage below, object and x represent an object of class inheriting from BaseSets, and value is an object of a class specified in the S4 method signature or as outlined in 'Accessors'.

relations(object)

relations(object) <- value

elements(object)

elementData(object)

elementData(object) <- value

sets(object)

setData(object)

setData(object) <- value

nElements(object)

nSets(object)

setLengths(object)

elementLengths(object)

# S4 method for BaseSets
relations(object)

# S4 method for BaseSets
relations(object) <- value

# S4 method for BaseSets
elementData(object)

# S4 method for BaseSets
elementData(object) <- value

# S4 method for BaseSets
setData(object)

# S4 method for BaseSets
setData(object) <- value

# S4 method for BaseSets
elements(object)

# S4 method for BaseSets
sets(object)

# S4 method for BaseSets
length(x)

# S4 method for BaseSets
nElements(object)

# S4 method for BaseSets
nSets(object)

# S4 method for BaseSets
setLengths(object)

# S4 method for BaseSets
elementLengths(object)

# S3 method for BaseSets
c(x, ...)

# S4 method for BaseSets,ANY,ANY,ANY
[(x, i, j, ..., drop = TRUE)

# S3 method for BaseSets
subset(x, ...)

# S4 method for BaseSets
duplicated(x, incomparables = FALSE, ...)

# S4 method for BaseSets
unique(x, incomparables = FALSE, ...)

union.BaseSets(x, y, ...)

as.DataFrame.BaseSets(object, ...)

# S3 method for BaseSets
as.data.frame(x, ...)

# S3 method for BaseSets
as.list(x, ...)

# S3 method for BaseSets
as.matrix(x, ...)

as.BaseSets.list(list, ...)

as.BaseSets.matrix(matrix, ...)

Arguments

object, x

An object of class inheriting from BaseSets.
value

An object of a class specified in the S4 method signature or as outlined in 'Accessors'.
...

Additional arguments passed to and from other methods.
i

index specifying elements to extract or replace.
j

Ignored.
drop

A logical scalar indicating whether to remove orphan elements and sets from the elementData and setData slots, respectively.
incomparables

Ignored.
y

An object of class inheriting from BaseSets.
list

A list of named character vectors. The names are taken as the set identifiers. The character vectors are taken as identifiers of elements that are member of each set.
matrix

A matrix. The matrix will be coerced to logical type and relations indicating TRUE will be stored in the BaseSets.

Accessors

relations(object) returns the relations slot. A Hits objets storing the integer index of elements (from) and sets (to) in the elementData and setData slots, respectively, and associated relation metadata (mcols).

elementData(object) returns the elementData slot. An IdVector objets storing the unique element identifiers (ids) and associated element metadata (mcols).

setData(object) returns the setData slot. An IdVector objets storing the unique set identifiers (ids) and associated set metadata (mcols).

elements(object) returns an IdVector element identifiers and associated metadata as ordered in relations(object)$element (i.e., of length equal to length(object)).

sets(object) returns an IdVector of set identifiers and associated metadata as ordered in relations(object)$set. (i.e., of length equal to length(object)).

Dimensions

length(x) returns the total count of relations.

nElements(object) returns the count of unique elements.

nSets(object) returns the count of unique sets.

setLengths(object) returns the count of relations per set.

elementLengths(object) returns the count of relations per element.

Combining

c(x, ...) combines its arguments

Subsetting

x[i, drop=TRUE] returns new BaseSets object of the same class as x made of the elements selected by i. i can be missing; an NA-free logical, numeric, or character vector or factor (as ordinary vector or Rle object); or an IntegerRanges object. The drop logical value controls whether the metadata of elements and sets orphaned during the subsetting should be removed from the elementData and setData slots, respectively.

subset(object, subset, ..., drop=TRUE) returns subsets of relations which meet conditions. The subset argument should be a logical expression referring to any of "element", "set", and any available relation metadata indicating elements or rows to keep: missing values are taken as false. The drop logical scalar controls whether elements and sets orphaned during the subsetting should be removed from the elementData and setData slots, respectively.

Duplication and uniqueness

duplicated(x) determines which relations of a BaseSets are duplicates of relations with smaller subscripts, and returns a logical vector indicating which relations are duplicates.

unique(x) returns a BaseSets like x but with duplicate relations removed.

union(x) returns a BaseSets composed of the union of relations in x and y.

Coercion from BaseSets

as(object, "DataFrame") and as.DataFrame(object) return a nested DataFrame including columns "element", "set", "relationData", "elementData", and "setData".

as(x, "data.frame") and as.data.frame(x) return a flattened data.frame including "element", "set", and columns in mcols(relations(x)) if any.

as(x, "list") and as.list(x) return a named list. Names are set identifiers, and values are character vectors of element identifiers.

as(x, "matrix") and as.matrix(x) return a matrix with elements as rows, sets as columns, and a logical value to indicate membership.

Coercion to BaseSets

as(list, "BaseSets") and as.BaseSets(object) return a BaseSets from a list of character vectors.

as(matrix, "BaseSets") and as.BaseSets(object) return a BaseSets from an incidence matrix.

See also

BaseSets.

Examples

# Constructor ----

# Visually intuitive definition of sets
sets <- list(
  set1=c("A", "B"),
  set2=c("B", "C", "D"),
  set3=c("E"))

bs <- as(sets, "BaseSets")
bs
#> BaseSets with 6 relations between 5 elements and 3 sets
#>       element         set
#>   <character> <character>
#> 1           A        set1
#> 2           B        set1
#> 3           B        set2
#> 4           C        set2
#> 5           D        set2
#> 6           E        set3
#> 
#> @elementData
#> IdVector of length 5 with 5 unique identifiers
#> Ids: A, B, C, D, ...
#> Metadata:  (0 columns)
#> 
#> @setData
#> IdVector of length 3 with 3 unique identifiers
#> Ids: set1, set2, set3
#> Metadata:  (0 columns)

# Accessors ----

relations(bs)
#> Hits object with 6 hits and 0 metadata columns:
#>            from        to
#>       <integer> <integer>
#>   [1]         1         1
#>   [2]         2         1
#>   [3]         2         2
#>   [4]         3         2
#>   [5]         4         2
#>   [6]         5         3
#>   -------
#>   nLnode: 5 / nRnode: 3

bs1 <- bs
mcols(relations(bs1))[["NEW"]] <- paste0("value", seq_len(length(bs1)))

elementData(bs)
#> IdVector of length 5 with 5 unique identifiers
#> Ids: A, B, C, D, ...
#> Metadata:  (0 columns)

bs1 <- bs
mcols(elementData(bs1))[["NEW"]] <- paste0("value", seq_len(nElements(bs1)))

setData(bs)
#> IdVector of length 3 with 3 unique identifiers
#> Ids: set1, set2, set3
#> Metadata:  (0 columns)

bs1 <- bs
mcols(setData(bs1))[["NEW"]] <- paste0("value", seq_len(nSets(bs1)))

elements(bs)
#> IdVector of length 6 with 5 unique identifiers
#> Ids: A, B, B, C, ...
#> Metadata:  (0 columns)
ids(elements(bs))
#> [1] "A" "B" "B" "C" "D" "E"
mcols(elements(bs))
#> DataFrame with 6 rows and 0 columns

sets(bs)
#> IdVector of length 6 with 3 unique identifiers
#> Ids: set1, set1, set2, set2, ...
#> Metadata:  (0 columns)
ids(sets(bs))
#> [1] "set1" "set1" "set2" "set2" "set2" "set3"
mcols(sets(bs))
#> DataFrame with 6 rows and 0 columns

# Dimensions ----

length(bs)
#> [1] 6
nElements(bs)
#> [1] 5
nSets(bs)
#> [1] 3
setLengths(bs)
#> set1 set2 set3 
#>    2    3    1 
elementLengths(bs)
#> A B C D E 
#> 1 2 1 1 1 

# Combining ----

bs1 <- c(bs, bs)

# Subsetting ----

bs1 <- bs[1:5]
bs1 <- bs[1:5, , drop=FALSE] # keep metadata of orphan elements and sets

bs1 <- subset(bs, set == "set1" | element == "E")
bs1
#> BaseSets with 3 relations between 3 elements and 2 sets
#>       element         set
#>   <character> <character>
#> 1           A        set1
#> 2           B        set1
#> 3           E        set3
#> 
#> @elementData
#> IdVector of length 3 with 3 unique identifiers
#> Ids: A, B, E
#> Metadata:  (0 columns)
#> 
#> @setData
#> IdVector of length 2 with 2 unique identifiers
#> Ids: set1, set3
#> Metadata:  (0 columns)

# Duplication and uniqueness ----

bs1 <- bs
relations(bs1) <- rep(relations(bs1), each=2)
table(duplicated(bs1))
#> 
#> FALSE  TRUE 
#>     6     6 
unique(bs1)
#> BaseSets with 6 relations between 5 elements and 3 sets
#>       element         set
#>   <character> <character>
#> 1           A        set1
#> 2           B        set1
#> 3           B        set2
#> 4           C        set2
#> 5           D        set2
#> 6           E        set3
#> 
#> @elementData
#> IdVector of length 5 with 5 unique identifiers
#> Ids: A, B, C, D, ...
#> Metadata:  (0 columns)
#> 
#> @setData
#> IdVector of length 3 with 3 unique identifiers
#> Ids: set1, set2, set3
#> Metadata:  (0 columns)
bs1 <- union(bs, bs)

# Coercion from BaseSets ----

DF1 <- as(bs, "DataFrame")

df1 <- as.data.frame(bs)

l1 <- as(bs, "list")

m1 <- as(bs, "matrix")

bs1 <- bs
mcols(relations(bs1))[["membership"]] <- runif(length(bs1))
fs <- as(bs1, "FuzzySets")

# Fetch a sample of GO annotations
library(org.Hs.eg.db)
#> Loading required package: AnnotationDbi
#> Loading required package: Biobase
#> Welcome to Bioconductor
#> 
#>     Vignettes contain introductory material; view with
#>     'browseVignettes()'. To cite Bioconductor, see
#>     'citation("Biobase")', and for packages 'citation("pkgname")'.
#> Loading required package: IRanges
#> 
gs <- import(org.Hs.egGO)
#> Loading required namespace: GO.db
#> 
#> 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns
#> Coercing evidence to factor
#> Coercing ontology to factor
bs1 <- as(gs, "BaseSets")
gs1 <- as(bs1, "GOSets")

# Coercion to BaseSets ----

# list
bs1 <- as(list(set1=c("A", "B"), set2=c("B", "C")), "BaseSets")
# matrix
bs1 <- as(m1, "BaseSets")
